column2: MISSISSIPPI PERMIT PRACTICE TEST
column4: Mississippi
column6: MS

column2: Question Text
column4: Answer1 Text
column6: Answer2 Text
column8: Answer3 Text

column2: 1. The picture shows:
column4: a speeding fines doubled sign.
column6: a reversible road sign.
column8: a railroad advance warning sign.

column2: 2. Where are yield signs usually placed?
column4: At intersections, if there is no marked stop line.
column6: Where auxiliary roads lead into major roads.
column8: Where major roads lead into  auxiliary roads.

column2: 3. This sign means:
column4: Not enter
column6: Detour to the right
column8: The road to the right is for one-way traffic only

column2: 4. If a pedestrian is in the middle of the street when your signal light changes to green, you should:
column4: wait until the pedestrian crosses the street before proceeding.
column6: proceed unless the pedestrian is in your lane.
column8: proceed because you have the right-of-way.

column2: 5. If the entrance lane is too short to allow acceleration to expressway speed, you should:
column4: reduce your speed to 15 MPH or less and blend with traffic.
column6: stop and wait for a large space in traffic.
column8: enter the expressway and accelerate quickly.

column2: 6. Drivers can not pass a vehicle on the left if:
column4: they approach the top of a hill on a two-way road and can not see over it.
column6: they can not safely return to the right lane before they reach a solid yellow center line for the right lane.
column8: All of the above.

column2: 7. To reduce road rage, you should:
column4: always signal your intention when changing lanes.
column6: use your horn frequently to warn other drivers.
column8: talk on your cell phone while driving.

column2: 8. If the entrance lane is too short to allow acceleration to highway speed, you should:
column4: stop and wait for a large gap in traffic, then enter the highway and accelerate quickly.
column6: go to the next entrance ramp.
column8: merge into highway traffic as soon as possible.

column2: 9. Regulatory signs are:
column4: green.
column6: yellow.
column8: white.

column2: 10. When you see a "merging traffic" sign on the freeway, you should:
column4: move to another lane to let traffic enter, if safe.
column6: slow down to allow traffic to enter.
column8: speed up to avoid congesting traffic.

column2: 11. This road sign means:
column4: Playground ahead
column6: School crossing
column8: Pedestrian crossing

column2: 12. This sign warns drivers of:
column4: a reduction of lanes.
column6: a bridge ahead, wide enough to accommodate two lanes of traffic, but with very little clearance.
column8: a dip in the road. Drivers should be ready to stop if the dip is filled with water.

column2: 13. What is the meaning of blue traffic signs?
column4: They give directional information.
column6: Blue indicates road user services.
column8: A blue background indicates a regulatory sign.

column2: 14. What should drivers do when they see this sign?
column4: Make sure the bridge is clear of oncoming traffic before they cross.
column6: Allow others to merge smoothly.
column8: Look to the left and right for other traffic.

column2: 15. The shape of a route sign tells you:
column4: the speed limit on that route.
column6: the type of route you are on.
column8: that the route you are on might be dangerous.

column2: 16. What is the first thing you should do if your wheels move off the pavement?
column4: Pull the steering wheel back.
column6: Pull over to the right and sound your horn to warn the other drivers.
column8: Ease your foot off the gas pedal and brake gently.

column2: 17. When approaching someone using a white cane or guide dog, drivers should:
column4: carefully drive around them.
column6: honk their horn as they proceed past them.
column8: stop until the person is well away from the roadway or path of travel.

column2: 18. This sign indicates:
column4: Phone service ahead
column6: Cell phone shop ahead
column8: Emergency line available

column2: 19. When entering a freeway, you should check traffic by:
column4: using the side mirror and looking over your shoulder.
column6: using both the inside and outside mirrors.
column8: using the inside mirror.

column2: 20. This road sign means:
column4: School zone
column6: School crossing
column8: Pedestrian crossing

column2: 21. If a tire blows out, drivers should:
column4: pull over quickly.
column6: hold the steering wheel tightly and use the brakes lightly.
column8: apply the brake firmly and hold it.

column2: 22. This road sign means:
column4: Winding road ahead
column6: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed
column8: Watch for vehicles entering from the side

column2: 23. To make a proper right turn:
column4: give the proper signal and get into the lane nearest the right curb.
column6: swing to the left before turning right.
column8: slow down and get into the lane nearest the centerline.

column2: 24. You have stopped for a train at a railroad crossing. After the train passes, you must:
column4: watch for vehicles that must stop at railroad crossings (school buses, vehicles carrying hazardous materials, etc.).
column6: look to see if another train is coming, then cross the tracks if it is safe to do so.
column8: All of the above.

column2: 25. When driving at night, if an approaching car is using its high-beams you should:
column4: look toward the right edge of the road.
column6: turn your lights on and off.
column8: look toward the left edge of the road.

column2: 26. When parking on a public road, drivers should:
column4: move as far away from traffic as possible.
column6: always park on the left side of the roadway.
column8: All of the above.

column2: 27. It is unlawful­ to:
column4: pass within 250 feet of any intersection.
column6: exceed the posted speed limit when passing.
column8: pass within 150 feet of any railroad crossing.

column2: 28. Having a drivers license is:
column4: a constitutional right.
column6: a privilege.
column8: a requirement.

column2: 29. No Zones are areas around trucks where cars:
column4: disappear into blind spots or are so close to the truck that the driver's ability to stop or maneuver safely is restricted.
column6: can turn safely because several car lengths have been left between the truck and car.
column8: can travel behind trucks at constant speed and have no risks of being involved in a collision.

column2: 30. If you have to wait for a space to enter a freeway, you should:
column4: maintain speed and signal other drivers to make a gap.
column6: slow down on the ramp and search ahead for a gap in traffic on the freeway.
column8: stop at the end of the ramp to wait for a gap in traffic.
